deck.definition: A portable computing device with a touchscreen interface.
A portable computer with an integrated screen, keyboard, and battery.
A server that hosts websites and responds to HTTP requests.
A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.
A device that forwards data packets between computer networks.
A device that connects devices on a local area network (LAN) and uses MAC addresses to forward data.
Intrusion Detection System - A system that monitors network or system activities for malicious activities.
Intrusion Prevention System - A system that not only detects but also prevents malicious activities in real-time.
A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network via Wi-Fi.
Software emulations of physical computers that run operating systems and applications.
A system used to send, receive, and store email messages.
The ability to connect to and use the internet.
A server that translates domain names into IP addresses.
Internet of Things devices are everyday objects that connect to the internet and can collect and exchange data.
Physical devices used for two-factor authentication (2FA), generating one-time passwords.
A mobile phone with advanced computing capabilities, including internet access and apps.
Network Interface Cards - Hardware that connects a computer to a network.
Devices that provide electrical power to a computer or network device.
Gigabit Interface Converters - A transceiver used for network communications.
Small Form-factor Pluggable transceivers - Modular connectors used for fiber optic or copper network links.
A switch that can be configured and managed remotely, often used in enterprise environments.
A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network via Wi-Fi.
Uninterruptible Power Supply - A device that provides backup power during power outages.
A tool used to analyze Wi-Fi networks and measure their signal strength and quality.
A tool used to map out network devices and their connections.
A tool used to analyze traffic flow data from network devices to monitor performance and detect anomalies.
The operating system developed by Microsoft, commonly used on personal computers and servers.
An open-source operating system based on the Linux kernel.
A Linux distribution based on Debian, used for penetration testing and security research.
Software used to capture network packets for analysis and troubleshooting.
Tools used for penetration testing to identify vulnerabilities in systems or networks.
Tools used for analyzing code either without executing it (static) or by running it (dynamic).
A tool used to scan networks or systems for known vulnerabilities.
Tools used to simulate network conditions for testing network configurations and troubleshooting.
Example source code used for reference or learning.
Software used to write, edit, and manage source code.
Security Information and Event Management - A system for monitoring and managing security events and logs.
Software or hardware used to capture and record keystrokes on a computer or mobile device.
Mobile Device Management software used to manage and secure mobile devices in an enterprise environment.
Virtual Private Network - A service that provides secure, encrypted communication over the internet.
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol service, which assigns IP addresses to devices on a network.
A service that resolves domain names to IP addresses.
The ability to access resources and services hosted on cloud platforms like AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud.
Documents or visual diagrams that describe the network infrastructure, topology, and components.
Example log files used for monitoring and analyzing system or network activity.
